metadata.titleEn: High-temporal-resolution water level and storage change data sets for lakes on the Tibetan Plateau during 2000-2017
metadata.description: The Tibetan Plateau, featuring the most extensive lake distribution in China, has seen rapid expansion of most its lakes. These lakes are important nodes for regional water and energy cycles, and highly sensitive to climate change. It is therefore imperative to unravel lake water storage changes under climate variation and change to improve the understanding of mechanisms of the interactions between regional hydrology and climate and their changes.  This developed data set provides water level, hypsometric curves, and lake storage changes for 52 large lakes across the TP from 2000 to 2017, comprising traditional altimetry water levels and a unique source of information termed as the optical water levels derived from tremendous amounts of Landsat archives using Google Earth Engine. Field experiments agree with the theoritical analysis that the uncertainty of optical water level is 0.1 - 0.2 m, comparable with that of altimetry water level. The uncertainty of altimetry water level is represented by the standard deviation of water levels obtained from effective footprints of the same cycle, which is included in the dataset. This dataset is applicable in water resource and security management, lake basin hydrological analysis, water balance analysis and the like. For instance, it has great potential in monitoring lake overflow flood.
metadata.instructions: This data set contains 52 time series of lake water level and lake storage change (52 text files), and one text file that stores hypsometric curves of all lakes. The format of the time series file name is "XXXX_Lake_water_ level_storage_changes", where XXXX represents the English name of the lake. It can be opened in Notepad. Besides the header file information, each time series file contains five columns of data, including data acquisition date, water level, water level uncertainty, lake storage change and data source. The header file contains the latitude and longitude of the lake and a detailed description of each column of data.

background: The Tibetan Plateau (TP), known as Asia’s water tower, is quite sensitive to climate change, which is reflected by changes in hydrologic state variables such as lake water storage. The Tibetan Plateau (TP), providing vital water resources for more than a billion population in Asia, is a sensitive region undergoing rapid climate change. There are more than 1200 alpine lakes larger than 1 km² on the TP, where glaciers and permafrost are also widely distributed. Lake storage changes that play an important role in the regional water balance can be derived from changes in lake water level and area. Lake water levels and areas are mostly derived from satellite remote sensing due to the scarcity of in situ data across the TP, where the harsh environment and complex terrain make in situ measurements difficult to perform and costly. Lake water levels can be monitored using satellite altimeters initially designed for sea surface topography or ice sheet/sea ice freeboard height measurements. Changes in lake area can be captured by optical or synthetic aperture radar (SAR) images from medium- or high-spatial-resolution remote sensing data, such as Landsat and Sentinel series. Automatic water extraction methods based on the water index and auto-thresholding are more efficient in dealing with a mass of remote sensing images.
research objective: The overall objective of this study was to examine multi-year and short-term changes in water level and storage across 52 lakes with surface areas larger than 150 km² on the TP by merging multisource altimetry and optical remote sensing images to generate more coherent high-temporal-resolution lake water level and storage change data sets ranging from weekly to monthly timescales during 2000–2017 and the hypsometric curve (i.e., the lake-area–water-level relationship) for each lake.
challenges: Given the extremely limited ground observations on the TP due to the harsh environment and complex terrain, we exploited multiple altimetric missions and Landsat satellite data. Acquisition and preprocessing of such a large amount of historical data (∼10 TB) covering TP lakes are still intractable for researchers with limited computational resources.
methods: First, water levels from various satellite altimeters for each lake as well as lake shoreline positions and lake areas from optical remote sensing images (i.e., Landsat) were derived. Second, systematic biases between different altimetry data were removed by either comparing the mean water levels during the overlap period or comparing the two water level time series with lake shoreline positions, depending on the length of the overlap period. Third, with information on lake water levels and areas derived from altimetry data and optical remote sensing images, the hypsometric curve that describes the relationship between the lake water level and storage changes can be derived. Fourth, the integral of the hypsometric curve was performed to convert lake water levels into storage changes.
dataset: The data sets are available online at https://doi.org/10.1594/PANGAEA.898411 (Li et al., 2019). In this study, more than 20,000 Landsat images were processed online using GEE to extract lake water bodies based on the water index and Otsu algorithm.

Definition.Question: What does 'hypsometric curve' mean in the context of lake water level and storage change studies on the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: In the context of lake water level and storage change studies on the Tibetan Plateau, a 'hypsometric curve' describes the relationship between the lake water level and storage changes. It is derived from information on lake water levels and areas obtained from altimetry data and optical remote sensing images.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'optical water level' in satellite-derived lake water level measurements?
Definition.Answer: 'Optical water level' refers to water level information derived by converting the observed changes in lake shorelines from optical satellite images, like Landsat, into water level data. This approach is used to remove systematic biases between different altimetry datasets.

Definition.Question: How are 'automatic water extraction methods' utilized in processing remote sensing images for lake studies?
Definition.Answer: In lake studies, 'automatic water extraction methods' are used to efficiently handle large volumes of remote sensing images by identifying water bodies. These methods often involve using water indices and algorithms, such as the Otsu algorithm, to process images from sources like the Landsat series on platforms like Google Earth Engine (GEE).

Comparison.Question: What are the challenges associated with using multi-source altimetry and Landsat satellite data compared to in situ measurements for lake monitoring on the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: The challenges with using multi-source altimetry and Landsat satellite data include the limited ground observations due to the harsh environment and complex terrain of the Tibetan Plateau. Additionally, acquiring and preprocessing the large volume of historical data, approximately 10 TB, covering the lakes is intractable for researchers with limited computational resources. In contrast, in situ measurements, though precise, are difficult and costly to perform in such environments.

Comparison.Question: In what ways does the use of the hypsometric curve enhance the understanding of lake water storage changes compared to traditional methods on the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: The hypsometric curve enhances understanding by describing the relationship between lake water level and storage changes, allowing for the conversion of lake water levels into storage changes. This method provides a more integrated approach compared to traditional methods, which may not fully capture the dynamic changes in water storage over time, especially in regions like the Tibetan Plateau where direct measurements are scarce.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in using remote sensing data to monitor lake water levels and areas on the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges include the harsh environment and complex terrain of the Tibetan Plateau, which limit ground observations and make in situ measurements difficult and costly. Additionally, acquiring and preprocessing a large volume of historical satellite data (approximately 10 TB) covering the lakes is intractable for researchers with limited computational resources. Systematic biases between different altimetry data also pose a challenge, requiring careful comparison and correction to ensure data accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: What are the implications of developing a hypsometric curve for understanding lake water level and storage changes in the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: Developing a hypsometric curve is crucial for understanding the relationship between lake water levels and storage changes. It allows researchers to convert water level measurements into estimates of storage change, providing valuable insights into the regional water balance. This information is essential for water resource management, hydrological analysis, and monitoring potential overflow or flooding events in the lakes of the Tibetan Plateau.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the reliance on satellite remote sensing for lake water level and area data collection on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The reliance on satellite remote sensing for lake water level and area data collection on the Tibetan Plateau is primarily due to the scarcity of in situ data across the region. This scarcity is caused by the harsh environment and complex terrain, which make in situ measurements difficult and costly to perform.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons behind the challenges faced in acquiring and preprocessing large amounts of historical data for Tibetan Plateau lakes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in acquiring and preprocessing large amounts of historical data for Tibetan Plateau lakes stem from the need to handle approximately 10 TB of data covering the lakes. Researchers with limited computational resources find it intractable to manage such extensive data, especially given the requirement to merge information from multiple altimetric missions and Landsat satellite data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need to remove systematic biases between different altimetry data when examining lake water levels on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: There is a need to remove systematic biases between different altimetry data when examining lake water levels on the Tibetan Plateau because these biases can affect the accuracy and coherence of the lake water level time series. Removing these biases is essential for ensuring that the data accurately reflects changes in lake water levels and storage, especially given the reliance on satellite altimetry due to limited ground observations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using satellite altimetry and optical remote sensing images to derive lake water levels and areas on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of satellite altimetry and optical remote sensing images allows for the monitoring of lake water levels and areas despite the scarcity of in situ data. This approach enables researchers to generate high-temporal-resolution datasets of lake water level and storage changes, which are crucial for understanding regional water balance and the impact of climate change on the Tibetan Plateau.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects of removing systematic biases between different altimetry data on the accuracy of lake water level measurements?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Removing systematic biases between different altimetry data increases the coherence and accuracy of lake water level measurements. This process ensures that the derived datasets accurately reflect changes in lake water levels and storage, facilitating reliable hydrological analysis and monitoring of regional water resources.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of merging multisource altimetry and optical remote sensing images to study lake water levels and storage changes on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The overall objective is to examine multi-year and short-term changes in water level and storage across 52 lakes on the Tibetan Plateau by generating high-temporal-resolution lake water level and storage change datasets ranging from weekly to monthly timescales during 2000–2017, and to produce the hypsometric curve for each lake.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to remove systematic biases between different altimetry data in the context of monitoring lake water levels on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Removing systematic biases is crucial to ensure the accuracy of water level data, which is derived from various satellite altimeters. This step is necessary to produce coherent data by either comparing mean water levels during overlap periods or comparing water level time series with lake shoreline positions, which is essential for reliable analysis of lake water levels and storage changes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What goals drive the use of optical remote sensing images in capturing changes in lake area on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The use of optical remote sensing images aims to effectively capture changes in lake area, which are fundamental to understanding lake storage changes. This method leverages medium- or high-spatial-resolution remote sensing data like Landsat to overcome the scarcity of in situ data and the challenges posed by the harsh and complex terrain of the Tibetan Plateau.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed to ensure high temporal resolution in lake water level and storage change data collection on the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To achieve high temporal resolution in lake water level and storage change data, multisource altimetry and optical remote sensing images are merged. Satellite altimeters are used for monitoring water levels, while optical remote sensing images like Landsat are used to derive lake shoreline positions and areas. Systematic biases between different altimetry data are removed by comparing mean water levels during overlap periods or by using lake shoreline positions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to convert optical remote sensing observations into accurate lake water level information?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves using optical remote sensing images to observe changes in lake shorelines, which are then converted into water level information. This conversion process involves deriving lake areas from optical images and using the hypsometric curve, which describes the relationship between lake water level and storage changes. The integral of this curve is performed to convert lake water levels into storage changes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are biases between different satellite altimetry data managed to ensure consistency in lake water level measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Biases between different satellite altimetry data are managed by either comparing the mean water levels during the overlap period of altimetry missions or by comparing the water level time series with lake shoreline positions, depending on the length of the overlap period. This ensures that systematic biases are removed, resulting in more coherent and accurate measurements.

Enablement.Question: How do automatic water extraction methods enhance the efficiency of processing large volumes of remote sensing images?
Enablement.Answer: Automatic water extraction methods, such as those based on the water index and Otsu algorithm, enhance efficiency by enabling the processing of more than 20,000 Landsat images online using platforms like Google Earth Engine (GEE) to extract lake water bodies, thereby managing a large amount of historical data efficiently.

Enablement.Question: What strategies are employed to overcome the challenges of limited ground observations in harsh environments like the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: To overcome the challenge of limited ground observations on the Tibetan Plateau, multiple altimetric missions and Landsat satellite data are exploited. Systematic biases between different altimetry data are removed by comparing mean water levels during overlap periods or with lake shoreline positions, facilitating the derivation of coherent data even in complex terrains.

Expectation.Question: Why might researchers expect challenges in processing a large amount of historical remote sensing data for lake level and storage changes on the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: The processing of a large amount of historical remote sensing data, approximately 10 TB, covering lakes on the Tibetan Plateau is challenging due to the limited computational resources available to researchers. Additionally, the extremely limited ground observations in the region, caused by the harsh environment and complex terrain, exacerbate these challenges.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected benefits of using multisource altimetry and optical remote sensing images in generating high-temporal-resolution lake water level datasets?
Expectation.Answer: By merging multisource altimetry and optical remote sensing images, researchers can generate more coherent high-temporal-resolution lake water level and storage change datasets. These datasets, with a temporal resolution ranging from weekly to monthly timescales, are expected to provide detailed insights into multi-year and short-term changes in water levels and storage, which are crucial for understanding regional water balance and hydrologic state variables on the Tibetan Plateau.

Expectation.Question: Why might the accuracy of lake water levels derived from optical remote sensing be comparable to that of satellite altimetry?
Expectation.Answer: The accuracy of lake water levels derived from optical remote sensing is comparable to satellite altimetry because the optical water levels are adjusted to remove systematic biases between different altimetry data. Field experiments and theoretical analyses indicate that the precision of optical water levels is within 0.1 to 0.2 meters, which is equivalent to the precision of altimetric measurements.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the challenges of acquiring and preprocessing large-scale historical data for lake water level monitoring in the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: Acquisition and preprocessing of large-scale historical data, approximately 10 TB, covering the Tibetan Plateau lakes are intractable for researchers with limited computational resources due to the harsh environment and complex terrain.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how can the integration of multisource altimetry and optical remote sensing images improve the temporal resolution of lake water storage change datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: By merging multisource altimetry and optical remote sensing images, researchers can generate coherent high-temporal-resolution lake water level and storage change datasets ranging from weekly to monthly timescales, thus significantly improving the temporal resolution.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how multisource satellite data can be effectively integrated to track changes in lake water levels and storage.
Assertion.Answer: Multisource satellite data can be effectively integrated by deriving water levels from various satellite altimeters and comparing them with lake shoreline positions and areas obtained from optical remote sensing images, such as Landsat. Systematic biases between different altimetry data are removed through comparisons during overlap periods or with shoreline positions, enabling coherent high-temporal-resolution data on lake water levels and storage changes.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how the hypsometric curve is used to convert lake water levels into storage changes.
Assertion.Answer: The hypsometric curve, which describes the relationship between lake water levels and storage changes, is derived from altimetry data and optical remote sensing images. The integral of this curve is performed to convert observed lake water levels into estimates of storage changes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges associated with the acquisition and preprocessing of satellite data for hydrologic studies on the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: The acquisition and preprocessing of satellite data for hydrologic studies on the Tibetan Plateau are challenging due to the large volume of historical data, approximately 10 TB, required to cover the lakes in the region. Limited computational resources further complicate these processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose methodologies to improve the integration of optical remote sensing images with altimetry data for more accurate lake water storage assessments.
Request/Directive.Answer: Improving the integration of optical remote sensing images with altimetry data involves removing systematic biases between different altimetry data sets, utilizing lake shoreline positions to validate water level time series, and deriving the hypsometric curve to accurately convert lake water levels into storage changes.
